### <span id="CustomEditorProvider"></span><span id="1978" class="code-item">CustomEditorProvider&lt;T&gt;</span>

Provider for editable custom editors that use a custom document model.

Custom editors use [`CustomDocument`](#CustomDocument) as their document model instead of a [`TextDocument`](#TextDocument). This gives extensions full control over actions such as edit, save, and backup.

You should use this type of custom editor when dealing with binary files or more complex scenarios. For simple text based documents, use [`CustomTextEditorProvider`](#CustomTextEditorProvider) instead.

#### Events

<span id="CustomEditorProvider.onDidChangeCustomDocument"></span><span id="1980" class="ts" data-target="#details-1980" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidChangeCustomDocument</span>: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<a href="#CustomDocumentEditEvent" class="type-ref">CustomDocumentEditEvent</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>&gt;&gt; | <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<a href="#CustomDocumentContentChangeEvent" class="type-ref">CustomDocumentContentChangeEvent</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>&gt;&gt;</span>

Signal that an edit has occurred inside a custom editor.

This event must be fired by your extension whenever an edit happens in a custom editor. An edit can be anything from changing some text, to cropping an image, to reordering a list. Your extension is free to define what an edit is and what data is stored on each edit.

Firing `onDidChange` causes VS Code to mark the editors as being dirty. This is cleared when the user either saves or reverts the file.

Editors that support undo/redo must fire a `CustomDocumentEditEvent` whenever an edit happens. This allows users to undo and redo the edit using VS Code's standard VS Code keyboard shortcuts. VS Code will also mark the editor as no longer being dirty if the user undoes all edits to the last saved state.

Editors that support editing but cannot use VS Code's standard undo/redo mechanism must fire a `CustomDocumentContentChangeEvent`. The only way for a user to clear the dirty state of an editor that does not support undo/redo is to either `save` or `revert` the file.

An editor should only ever fire `CustomDocumentEditEvent` events, or only ever fire `CustomDocumentContentChangeEvent` events.

#### Methods

<span id="CustomEditorProvider.backupCustomDocument"></span><span id="1995" class="ts" data-target="#details-1995" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">backupCustomDocument</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>, <span class="ident">context</span>: <a href="#CustomDocumentBackupContext" class="type-ref">CustomDocumentBackupContext</a>, <span class="ident">cancellation</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<a href="#CustomDocumentBackup" class="type-ref">CustomDocumentBackup</a>&gt;</span>

Back up a dirty custom document.

Backups are used for hot exit and to prevent data loss. Your `backup` method should persist the resource in its current state, i.e. with the edits applied. Most commonly this means saving the resource to disk in the `ExtensionContext.storagePath`. When VS Code reloads and your custom editor is opened for a resource, your extension should first check to see if any backups exist for the resource. If there is a backup, your extension should load the file contents from there instead of from the resource in the workspace.

`backup` is triggered approximately one second after the user stops editing the document. If the user rapidly edits the document, `backup` will not be invoked until the editing stops.

`backup` is not invoked when `auto save` is enabled (since auto save already persists the resource).

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="document"></span><span id="1996" class="ts" data-target="#details-1996" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">document</span><span>: </span><span class="type-intrinsic">T</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>Document to backup.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span id="context"></span><span id="1997" class="ts" data-target="#details-1997" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">context</span><span>: </span><a href="#CustomDocumentBackupContext" class="type-ref">CustomDocumentBackupContext</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>Information that can be used to backup the document.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span id="cancellation"></span><span id="1998" class="ts" data-target="#details-1998" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">cancellation</span><span>: </span><a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>Token that signals the current backup since a new backup is coming in. It is up to your extension to decided how to respond to cancellation. If for example your extension is backing up a large file in an operation that takes time to complete, your extension may decide to finish the ongoing backup rather than cancelling it to ensure that VS Code has some valid backup.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<a href="#CustomDocumentBackup" class="type-ref">CustomDocumentBackup</a>&gt;</span></td><td><div class="comment"></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="CustomEditorProvider.openCustomDocument"></span><span id="2000" class="ts" data-target="#details-2000" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">openCustomDocument</span>(<span class="ident">uri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, <span class="ident">openContext</span>: <a href="#CustomDocumentOpenContext" class="type-ref">CustomDocumentOpenContext</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>&gt; | <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span></span>

Create a new document for a given resource.

`openCustomDocument` is called when the first time an editor for a given resource is opened. The opened document is then passed to `resolveCustomEditor` so that the editor can be shown to the user.

Already opened `CustomDocument` are re-used if the user opened additional editors. When all editors for a given resource are closed, the `CustomDocument` is disposed of. Opening an editor at this point will trigger another call to `openCustomDocument`.

<span id="CustomEditorProvider.resolveCustomEditor"></span><span id="2005" class="ts" data-target="#details-2005" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">resolveCustomEditor</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>, <span class="ident">webviewPanel</span>: <a href="#WebviewPanel" class="type-ref">WebviewPanel</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt; | <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span>

Resolve a custom editor for a given resource.

This is called whenever the user opens a new editor for this `CustomEditorProvider`.

The provider can also hold onto the <code>WebviewPanel</code> to use later for example in a command. See <a href="#WebviewPanel"><code>WebviewPanel</code></a> for additional details.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span id="token"></span><span id="2008" class="ts" data-target="#details-2008" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">token</span><span>: </span><a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A cancellation token that indicates the result is no longer needed.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt; | <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>Optional thenable indicating that the custom editor has been resolved.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="CustomEditorProvider.revertCustomDocument"></span><span id="1991" class="ts" data-target="#details-1991" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">revertCustomDocument</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>, <span class="ident">cancellation</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

Revert a custom document to its last saved state.

This method is invoked by VS Code when the user triggers `File: Revert File` in a custom editor. (Note that this is only used using VS Code's `File: Revert File` command and not on a `git revert` of the file).

To implement `revert`, the implementer must make sure all editor instances (webviews) for `document` are displaying the document in the same state is saved in. This usually means reloading the file from the workspace.

<span id="CustomEditorProvider.saveCustomDocument"></span><span id="1982" class="ts" data-target="#details-1982" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">saveCustomDocument</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>, <span class="ident">cancellation</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

Save a custom document.

This method is invoked by VS Code when the user saves a custom editor. This can happen when the user triggers save while the custom editor is active, by commands such as `save all`, or by auto save if enabled.

To implement `save`, the implementer must persist the custom editor. This usually means writing the file data for the custom document to disk. After `save` completes, any associated editor instances will no longer be marked as dirty.

<span id="CustomEditorProvider.saveCustomDocumentAs"></span><span id="1986" class="ts" data-target="#details-1986" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">saveCustomDocumentAs</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>, <span class="ident">destination</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, <span class="ident">cancellation</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

Save a custom document to a different location.

This method is invoked by VS Code when the user triggers ‘save as’ on a custom editor. The implementer must persist the custom editor to `destination`.

When the user accepts save as, the current editor is be replaced by an non-dirty editor for the newly saved file.

### <span id="CustomExecution"></span><span id="1672" class="code-item">CustomExecution</span>

Class used to execute an extension callback as a task.

#### Constructors

<span id="CustomExecution.new CustomExecution"></span><span id="1674" class="ts" data-target="#details-1674" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">new CustomExecution</span>(<span class="ident">callback</span>: (resolvedDefinition: <a href="#TaskDefinition" class="type-ref">TaskDefinition</a>) =&gt; <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<a href="#Pseudoterminal" class="type-ref">Pseudoterminal</a>&gt;): <a href="#CustomExecution" class="type-ref">CustomExecution</a></span>

Constructs a CustomExecution task object. The callback will be executed the task is run, at which point the extension should return the Pseudoterminal it will “run in”. The task should wait to do further execution until [Pseudoterminal.open](#Pseudoterminal.open) is called. Task cancellation should be handled using [Pseudoterminal.close](#Pseudoterminal.close). When the task is complete fire [Pseudoterminal.onDidClose](#Pseudoterminal.onDidClose).

### <span id="CustomReadonlyEditorProvider"></span><span id="1966" class="code-item">CustomReadonlyEditorProvider&lt;T&gt;</span>

Provider for readonly custom editors that use a custom document model.

Custom editors use [`CustomDocument`](#CustomDocument) as their document model instead of a [`TextDocument`](#TextDocument).

You should use this type of custom editor when dealing with binary files or more complex scenarios. For simple text based documents, use [`CustomTextEditorProvider`](#CustomTextEditorProvider) instead.

#### Methods

<span id="CustomReadonlyEditorProvider.openCustomDocument"></span><span id="1969" class="ts" data-target="#details-1969" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">openCustomDocument</span>(<span class="ident">uri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, <span class="ident">openContext</span>: <a href="#CustomDocumentOpenContext" class="type-ref">CustomDocumentOpenContext</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>&gt; | <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span></span>

Create a new document for a given resource.

`openCustomDocument` is called when the first time an editor for a given resource is opened. The opened document is then passed to `resolveCustomEditor` so that the editor can be shown to the user.

Already opened `CustomDocument` are re-used if the user opened additional editors. When all editors for a given resource are closed, the `CustomDocument` is disposed of. Opening an editor at this point will trigger another call to `openCustomDocument`.

This is called whenever the user opens a new editor for this `CustomEditorProvider`.

### <span id="CustomTextEditorProvider"></span><span id="1937" class="code-item">CustomTextEditorProvider</span>

Provider for text based custom editors.

Text based custom editors use a [`TextDocument`](#TextDocument) as their data model. This considerably simplifies implementing a custom editor as it allows VS Code to handle many common operations such as undo and backup. The provider is responsible for synchronizing text changes between the webview and the `TextDocument`.

#### Methods

<span id="CustomTextEditorProvider.resolveCustomTextEditor"></span><span id="1939" class="ts" data-target="#details-1939" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">resolveCustomTextEditor</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <a href="#TextDocument" class="type-ref">TextDocument</a>, <span class="ident">webviewPanel</span>: <a href="#WebviewPanel" class="type-ref">WebviewPanel</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt; | <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span>

Resolve a custom editor for a given text resource.

This is called when a user first opens a resource for a `CustomTextEditorProvider`, or if they reopen an existing editor using this `CustomTextEditorProvider`.

<span id="DebugAdapterDescriptor"></span><span id="3142" class="ts" data-target="#details-3142" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">DebugAdapterDescriptor</span>: <a href="#DebugAdapterExecutable" class="type-ref">DebugAdapterExecutable</a> | <a href="#DebugAdapterServer" class="type-ref">DebugAdapterServer</a> | <a href="#DebugAdapterNamedPipeServer" class="type-ref">DebugAdapterNamedPipeServer</a> | <a href="#DebugAdapterInlineImplementation" class="type-ref">DebugAdapterInlineImplementation</a></span>

#### Methods

<span id="DebugAdapterDescriptorFactory.createDebugAdapterDescriptor"></span><span id="2465" class="ts" data-target="#details-2465" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">createDebugAdapterDescriptor</span>(<span class="ident">session</span>: <a href="#DebugSession" class="type-ref">DebugSession</a>, <span class="ident">executable</span>: <a href="#DebugAdapterExecutable" class="type-ref">DebugAdapterExecutable</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#DebugAdapterDescriptor" class="type-ref">DebugAdapterDescriptor</a>&gt;</span>

‘createDebugAdapterDescriptor’ is called at the start of a debug session to provide details about the debug adapter to use. These details must be returned as objects of type [DebugAdapterDescriptor](#DebugAdapterDescriptor). Currently two types of debug adapters are supported:

- a debug adapter executable is specified as a command path and arguments (see [DebugAdapterExecutable](#DebugAdapterExecutable)),
- a debug adapter server reachable via a communication port (see [DebugAdapterServer](#DebugAdapterServer)). If the method is not implemented the default behavior is this: createDebugAdapter(session: DebugSession, executable: DebugAdapterExecutable) { if (typeof session.configuration.debugServer === ‘number’) {

        return new DebugAdapterServer(session.configuration.debugServer);

  } return executable; }

### <span id="DebugConfigurationProvider"></span><span id="2400" class="code-item">DebugConfigurationProvider</span>

A debug configuration provider allows to add debug configurations to the debug service and to resolve launch configurations before they are used to start a debug session. A debug configuration provider is registered via \#debug.registerDebugConfigurationProvider.

#### Methods

<span id="DebugConfigurationProvider.provideDebugConfigurations"></span><span id="2402" class="ts" data-target="#details-2402" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">provideDebugConfigurations</span>(<span class="ident">folder</span>: <a href="#WorkspaceFolder" class="type-ref">WorkspaceFolder</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span>, <span class="ident">token</span>?: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a>\[\]&gt;</span>

Provides [debug configuration](#DebugConfiguration) to the debug service. If more than one debug configuration provider is registered for the same type, debug configurations are concatenated in arbitrary order.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="folder"></span><span id="2403" class="ts" data-target="#details-2403" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">folder</span><span>: </span><a href="#WorkspaceFolder" class="type-ref">WorkspaceFolder</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The workspace folder for which the configurations are used or <code>undefined</code> for a folderless setup.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span id="token"></span><span id="2404" class="ts" data-target="#details-2404" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">token</span><span>?</span><span>: </span><a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A cancellation token.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a>[]&gt;</span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>An array of <a href="#DebugConfiguration">debug configurations</a>.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="DebugConfigurationProvider.resolveDebugConfiguration"></span><span id="2406" class="ts" data-target="#details-2406" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">resolveDebugConfiguration</span>(<span class="ident">folder</span>: <a href="#WorkspaceFolder" class="type-ref">WorkspaceFolder</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span>, <span class="ident">debugConfiguration</span>: <a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>?: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a>&gt;</span>

Resolves a [debug configuration](#DebugConfiguration) by filling in missing values or by adding/changing/removing attributes. If more than one debug configuration provider is registered for the same type, the resolveDebugConfiguration calls are chained in arbitrary order and the initial debug configuration is piped through the chain. Returning the value ‘undefined’ prevents the debug session from starting. Returning the value ‘null’ prevents the debug session from starting and opens the underlying debug configuration instead.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="folder"></span><span id="2407" class="ts" data-target="#details-2407" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">folder</span><span>: </span><a href="#WorkspaceFolder" class="type-ref">WorkspaceFolder</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The workspace folder from which the configuration originates from or <code>undefined</code> for a folderless setup.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span id="debugConfiguration"></span><span id="2408" class="ts" data-target="#details-2408" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">debugConfiguration</span><span>: </span><a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The <a href="#DebugConfiguration">debug configuration</a> to resolve.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span id="token"></span><span id="2409" class="ts" data-target="#details-2409" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">token</span><span>?</span><span>: </span><a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A cancellation token.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a>&gt;</span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The resolved debug configuration or undefined or null.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="DebugConfigurationProvider.resolveDebugConfigurationWithSubstitutedVariables"></span><span id="2411" class="ts" data-target="#details-2411" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">resolveDebugConfigurationWithSubstitutedVariables</span>(<span class="ident">folder</span>: <a href="#WorkspaceFolder" class="type-ref">WorkspaceFolder</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span>, <span class="ident">debugConfiguration</span>: <a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>?: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a>&gt;</span>

This hook is directly called after ‘resolveDebugConfiguration’ but with all variables substituted. It can be used to resolve or verify a [debug configuration](#DebugConfiguration) by filling in missing values or by adding/changing/removing attributes. If more than one debug configuration provider is registered for the same type, the ‘resolveDebugConfigurationWithSubstitutedVariables’ calls are chained in arbitrary order and the initial debug configuration is piped through the chain. Returning the value ‘undefined’ prevents the debug session from starting. Returning the value ‘null’ prevents the debug session from starting and opens the underlying debug configuration instead.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="folder"></span><span id="2412" class="ts" data-target="#details-2412" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">folder</span><span>: </span><a href="#WorkspaceFolder" class="type-ref">WorkspaceFolder</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The workspace folder from which the configuration originates from or <code>undefined</code> for a folderless setup.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span id="debugConfiguration"></span><span id="2413" class="ts" data-target="#details-2413" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">debugConfiguration</span><span>: </span><a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The <a href="#DebugConfiguration">debug configuration</a> to resolve.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span id="token"></span><span id="2414" class="ts" data-target="#details-2414" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">token</span><span>?</span><span>: </span><a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A cancellation token.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#DebugConfiguration" class="type-ref">DebugConfiguration</a>&gt;</span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The resolved debug configuration or undefined or null.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

### <span id="DebugConfigurationProviderTriggerKind"></span><span id="2549" class="code-item">DebugConfigurationProviderTriggerKind</span>

A DebugConfigurationProviderTriggerKind specifies when the `provideDebugConfigurations` method of a `DebugConfigurationProvider` is triggered. Currently there are two situations: to provide the initial debug configurations for a newly created launch.json or to provide dynamically generated debug configurations when the user asks for them through the UI (e.g. via the “Select and Start Debugging” command). A trigger kind is used when registering a `DebugConfigurationProvider` with \#debug.registerDebugConfigurationProvider.

### <span id="DebugSessionOptions"></span><span id="2544" class="code-item">DebugSessionOptions</span>

Options for [starting a debug session](#debug.startDebugging).

#### Properties

<span id="DebugSessionOptions.compact"></span><span id="2548" class="ts" data-target="#details-2548" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">compact</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Controls if the debug session's parent session is shown in the CALL STACK view even if it has only a single child. By default, the debug session will never hide its parent. If compact is true, debug sessions with a single child are hidden in the CALL STACK view to make the tree more compact.

<span id="DebugSessionOptions.consoleMode"></span><span id="2546" class="ts" data-target="#details-2546" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">consoleMode</span>?: <a href="#DebugConsoleMode" class="type-ref">DebugConsoleMode</a></span>

Controls whether this session should have a separate debug console or share it with the parent session. Has no effect for sessions which do not have a parent session. Defaults to Separate.

<span id="DebugSessionOptions.noDebug"></span><span id="2547" class="ts" data-target="#details-2547" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">noDebug</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

### <span id="DiagnosticCollection"></span><span id="1410" class="code-item">DiagnosticCollection</span>

A diagnostics collection is a container that manages a set of [diagnostics](#Diagnostic). Diagnostics are always scopes to a diagnostics collection and a resource.

To get an instance of a `DiagnosticCollection` use [createDiagnosticCollection](#languages.createDiagnosticCollection).

#### Properties

#### Methods

### <span id="DocumentFilter"></span><span id="556" class="code-item">DocumentFilter</span>

A document filter denotes a document by different properties like the [language](#TextDocument.languageId), the [scheme](#Uri.scheme) of its resource, or a glob-pattern that is applied to the [path](#TextDocument.fileName).

- _example_ -
  A language filter that applies to typescript files on disk
  { language: ‘typescript’, scheme: ‘file’ }

<!-- -->

- _example_ -
  A language filter that applies to all package.json paths
  { language: ‘json’, scheme: ‘untitled’, pattern: '\*\*/package.json' }

#### Properties

<span id="DocumentFilter.language"></span><span id="557" class="ts" data-target="#details-557" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">language</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A language id, like `typescript`.

<span id="DocumentFilter.pattern"></span><span id="559" class="ts" data-target="#details-559" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">pattern</span>?: <a href="#GlobPattern" class="type-ref">GlobPattern</a></span>

A [glob pattern](#GlobPattern) that is matched on the absolute path of the document. Use a [relative pattern](#RelativePattern) to filter documents to a [workspace folder](#WorkspaceFolder).

<span id="DocumentFilter.scheme"></span><span id="558" class="ts" data-target="#details-558" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">scheme</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A Uri [scheme](#Uri.scheme), like `file` or `untitled`.

### <span id="DocumentSemanticTokensProvider"></span><span id="988" class="code-item">DocumentSemanticTokensProvider</span>

The document semantic tokens provider interface defines the contract between extensions and semantic tokens.

#### Events

<span id="DocumentSemanticTokensProvider.onDidChangeSemanticTokens"></span><span id="989" class="ts" data-target="#details-989" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidChangeSemanticTokens</span>?: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

An optional event to signal that the semantic tokens from this provider have changed.

#### Methods

<span id="DocumentSemanticTokensProvider.provideDocumentSemanticTokens"></span><span id="991" class="ts" data-target="#details-991" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">provideDocumentSemanticTokens</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <a href="#TextDocument" class="type-ref">TextDocument</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#SemanticTokens" class="type-ref">SemanticTokens</a>&gt;</span>

Tokens in a file are represented as an array of integers. The position of each token is expressed relative to the token before it, because most tokens remain stable relative to each other when edits are made in a file.

---

In short, each token takes 5 integers to represent, so a specific token `i` in the file consists of the following array indices:

- at index `5*i` - `deltaLine`: token line number, relative to the previous token
- at index `5*i+1` - `deltaStart`: token start character, relative to the previous token (relative to 0 or the previous token's start if they are on the same line)
- at index `5*i+2` - `length`: the length of the token. A token cannot be multiline.
- at index `5*i+3` - `tokenType`: will be looked up in `SemanticTokensLegend.tokenTypes`. We currently ask that `tokenType` &lt; 65536.
- at index `5*i+4` - `tokenModifiers`: each set bit will be looked up in `SemanticTokensLegend.tokenModifiers`

---

### How to encode tokens

Here is an example for encoding a file with 3 tokens in a uint32 array:

       { line: 2, startChar:  5, length: 3, tokenType: "property",  tokenModifiers: ["private", "static"] },
       { line: 2, startChar: 10, length: 4, tokenType: "type",      tokenModifiers: [] },
       { line: 5, startChar:  2, length: 7, tokenType: "class",     tokenModifiers: [] }

1.  First of all, a legend must be devised. This legend must be provided up-front and capture all possible token types. For this example, we will choose the following legend which must be passed in when registering the provider:

        tokenTypes: ['property', 'type', 'class'],
        tokenModifiers: ['private', 'static']

2.  The first transformation step is to encode `tokenType` and `tokenModifiers` as integers using the legend. Token types are looked up by index, so a `tokenType` value of `1` means `tokenTypes[1]`. Multiple token modifiers can be set by using bit flags, so a `tokenModifier` value of `3` is first viewed as binary `0b00000011`, which means `[tokenModifiers[0], tokenModifiers[1]]` because bits 0 and 1 are set. Using this legend, the tokens now are:

        { line: 2, startChar:  5, length: 3, tokenType: 0, tokenModifiers: 3 },
        { line: 2, startChar: 10, length: 4, tokenType: 1, tokenModifiers: 0 },
        { line: 5, startChar:  2, length: 7, tokenType: 2, tokenModifiers: 0 }

3.  The next step is to represent each token relative to the previous token in the file. In this case, the second token is on the same line as the first token, so the `startChar` of the second token is made relative to the `startChar` of the first token, so it will be `10 - 5`. The third token is on a different line than the second token, so the `startChar` of the third token will not be altered:

        { deltaLine: 2, deltaStartChar: 5, length: 3, tokenType: 0, tokenModifiers: 3 },
        { deltaLine: 0, deltaStartChar: 5, length: 4, tokenType: 1, tokenModifiers: 0 },
        { deltaLine: 3, deltaStartChar: 2, length: 7, tokenType: 2, tokenModifiers: 0 }

4.  Finally, the last step is to inline each of the 5 fields for a token in a single array, which is a memory friendly representation:

        // 1st token,  2nd token,  3rd token
        [  2,5,3,0,3,  0,5,4,1,0,  3,2,7,2,0 ]

- _see_ - [SemanticTokensBuilder](#SemanticTokensBuilder) for a helper to encode tokens as integers. _NOTE_: When doing edits, it is possible that multiple edits occur until VS Code decides to invoke the semantic tokens provider. _NOTE_: If the provider cannot temporarily compute semantic tokens, it can indicate this by throwing an error with the message ‘Busy’.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="document"></span><span id="992" class="ts" data-target="#details-992" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">document</span><span>: </span><a href="#TextDocument" class="type-ref">TextDocument</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span id="token"></span><span id="993" class="ts" data-target="#details-993" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">token</span><span>: </span><a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#SemanticTokens" class="type-ref">SemanticTokens</a>&gt;</span></td><td><div class="comment"></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="DocumentSemanticTokensProvider.provideDocumentSemanticTokensEdits"></span><span id="995" class="ts" data-target="#details-995" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">provideDocumentSemanticTokensEdits</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <a href="#TextDocument" class="type-ref">TextDocument</a>, <span class="ident">previousResultId</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#SemanticTokens" class="type-ref">SemanticTokens</a> | <a href="#SemanticTokensEdits" class="type-ref">SemanticTokensEdits</a>&gt;</span>

Instead of always returning all the tokens in a file, it is possible for a `DocumentSemanticTokensProvider` to implement this method (`provideDocumentSemanticTokensEdits`) and then return incremental updates to the previously provided semantic tokens.

---

### How tokens change when the document changes

Suppose that `provideDocumentSemanticTokens` has previously returned the following semantic tokens:

       // 1st token,  2nd token,  3rd token
       [  2,5,3,0,3,  0,5,4,1,0,  3,2,7,2,0 ]

Also suppose that after some edits, the new semantic tokens in a file are:

       // 1st token,  2nd token,  3rd token
       [  3,5,3,0,3,  0,5,4,1,0,  3,2,7,2,0 ]

It is possible to express these new tokens in terms of an edit applied to the previous tokens:

       [  2,5,3,0,3,  0,5,4,1,0,  3,2,7,2,0 ] // old tokens
       [  3,5,3,0,3,  0,5,4,1,0,  3,2,7,2,0 ] // new tokens

       edit: { start:  0, deleteCount: 1, data: [3] } // replace integer at offset 0 with 3

_NOTE_: If the provider cannot compute `SemanticTokensEdits`, it can “give up” and return all the tokens in the document again. _NOTE_: All edits in `SemanticTokensEdits` contain indices in the old integers array, so they all refer to the previous result state.

### <span id="DocumentSymbol"></span><span id="769" class="code-item">DocumentSymbol</span>

Represents programming constructs like variables, classes, interfaces etc. that appear in a document. Document symbols can be hierarchical and they have two ranges: one that encloses its definition and one that points to its most interesting range, e.g. the range of an identifier.

#### Constructors

### <span id="EnvironmentVariableCollection"></span><span id="2146" class="code-item">EnvironmentVariableCollection</span>

A collection of mutations that an extension can apply to a process environment.

#### Properties

<span id="EnvironmentVariableCollection.persistent"></span><span id="2147" class="ts" data-target="#details-2147" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">persistent</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Whether the collection should be cached for the workspace and applied to the terminal across window reloads. When true the collection will be active immediately such when the window reloads. Additionally, this API will return the cached version if it exists. The collection will be invalidated when the extension is uninstalled or when the collection is cleared. Defaults to true.

### <span id="EvaluatableExpression"></span><span id="692" class="code-item">EvaluatableExpression</span>

An EvaluatableExpression represents an expression in a document that can be evaluated by an active debugger or runtime. The result of this evaluation is shown in a tooltip-like widget. If only a range is specified, the expression will be extracted from the underlying document. An optional expression can be used to override the extracted expression. In this case the range is still used to highlight the range in the document.

### <span id="EvaluatableExpressionProvider"></span><span id="699" class="code-item">EvaluatableExpressionProvider</span>

The evaluatable expression provider interface defines the contract between extensions and the debug hover. In this contract the provider returns an evaluatable expression for a given position in a document and VS Code evaluates this expression in the active debug session and shows the result in a debug hover.

#### Methods

<span id="EvaluatableExpressionProvider.provideEvaluatableExpression"></span><span id="701" class="ts" data-target="#details-701" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">provideEvaluatableExpression</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <a href="#TextDocument" class="type-ref">TextDocument</a>, <span class="ident">position</span>: <a href="#Position" class="type-ref">Position</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#EvaluatableExpression" class="type-ref">EvaluatableExpression</a>&gt;</span>

Provide an evaluatable expression for the given document and position. VS Code will evaluate this expression in the active debug session and will show the result in the debug hover. The expression can be implicitly specified by the range in the underlying document or by explicitly returning an expression.

### <span id="EventEmitter"></span><span id="464" class="code-item">EventEmitter&lt;T&gt;</span>

An event emitter can be used to create and manage an [event](#Event) for others to subscribe to. One emitter always owns one event.

Use this class if you want to provide event from within your extension, for instance inside a [TextDocumentContentProvider](#TextDocumentContentProvider) or when providing API to other extensions.

### <span id="ExtensionContext"></span><span id="1547" class="code-item">ExtensionContext</span>

An extension context is a collection of utilities private to an extension.

An instance of an `ExtensionContext` is provided as the first parameter to the `activate`-call of an extension.

#### Properties

<span id="ExtensionContext.environmentVariableCollection"></span><span id="1560" class="ts" data-target="#details-1560" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">environmentVariableCollection</span>: <a href="#EnvironmentVariableCollection" class="type-ref">EnvironmentVariableCollection</a></span>

Gets the extension's environment variable collection for this workspace, enabling changes to be applied to terminal environment variables.

<span id="ExtensionContext.extensionMode"></span><span id="1570" class="ts" data-target="#details-1570" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">extensionMode</span>: <a href="#ExtensionMode" class="type-ref">ExtensionMode</a></span>

The mode the extension is running in. This is specific to the current extension. One extension may be in `ExtensionMode.Development` while other extensions in the host run in `ExtensionMode.Release`.

<span id="ExtensionContext.extensionPath"></span><span id="1559" class="ts" data-target="#details-1559" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">extensionPath</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

The absolute file path of the directory containing the extension. Shorthand notation for [ExtensionContext.extensionUri.fsPath](#TextDocument.uri) (independent of the uri scheme).

<span id="ExtensionContext.extensionUri"></span><span id="1558" class="ts" data-target="#details-1558" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">extensionUri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

The uri of the directory containing the extension.

<span id="ExtensionContext.globalState"></span><span id="1553" class="ts" data-target="#details-1553" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">globalState</span>: <a href="#Memento" class="type-ref">Memento</a> & {setKeysForSync}</span>

A memento object that stores state independent of the current opened [workspace](#workspace.workspaceFolders).

<span id="ExtensionContext.globalStoragePath"></span><span id="1567" class="ts" data-target="#details-1567" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">globalStoragePath</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

An absolute file path in which the extension can store global state. The directory might not exist on disk and creation is up to the extension. However, the parent directory is guaranteed to be existent.

Use [`globalState`](#ExtensionContext.globalState) to store key value data.

- _deprecated_ - Use [globalStorageUri](#ExtensionContext.globalStorageUri) instead.

<span id="ExtensionContext.globalStorageUri"></span><span id="1566" class="ts" data-target="#details-1566" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">globalStorageUri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

The uri of a directory in which the extension can store global state. The directory might not exist on disk and creation is up to the extension. However, the parent directory is guaranteed to be existent.

Use [`globalState`](#ExtensionContext.globalState) to store key value data.

- _see_ - [`workspace.fs`](#FileSystem) for how to read and write files and folders from an uri.

<span id="ExtensionContext.logPath"></span><span id="1569" class="ts" data-target="#details-1569" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">logPath</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

An absolute file path of a directory in which the extension can create log files. The directory might not exist on disk and creation is up to the extension. However, the parent directory is guaranteed to be existent.

- _deprecated_ - Use [logUri](#ExtensionContext.logUri) instead.

<span id="ExtensionContext.logUri"></span><span id="1568" class="ts" data-target="#details-1568" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">logUri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

The uri of a directory in which the extension can create log files. The directory might not exist on disk and creation is up to the extension. However, the parent directory is guaranteed to be existent.

- _see_ - [`workspace.fs`](#FileSystem) for how to read and write files and folders from an uri.

<span id="ExtensionContext.storagePath"></span><span id="1565" class="ts" data-target="#details-1565" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">storagePath</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span>

An absolute file path of a workspace specific directory in which the extension can store private state. The directory might not exist on disk and creation is up to the extension. However, the parent directory is guaranteed to be existent.

Use [`workspaceState`](#ExtensionContext.workspaceState) or [`globalState`](#ExtensionContext.globalState) to store key value data.

- _deprecated_ - Use [storageUri](#ExtensionContext.storageUri) instead.

<span id="ExtensionContext.storageUri"></span><span id="1564" class="ts" data-target="#details-1564" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">storageUri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span>

The uri of a workspace specific directory in which the extension can store private state. The directory might not exist and creation is up to the extension. However, the parent directory is guaranteed to be existent. The value is `undefined` when no workspace nor folder has been opened.

Use [`workspaceState`](#ExtensionContext.workspaceState) or [`globalState`](#ExtensionContext.globalState) to store key value data.

- _see_ - [`workspace.fs`](#FileSystem) for how to read and write files and folders from an uri.

<span id="ExtensionContext.subscriptions"></span><span id="1548" class="ts" data-target="#details-1548" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">subscriptions</span>: {dispose}\[\]</span>

An array to which disposables can be added. When this extension is deactivated the disposables will be disposed.

<span id="ExtensionContext.workspaceState"></span><span id="1552" class="ts" data-target="#details-1552" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">workspaceState</span>: <a href="#Memento" class="type-ref">Memento</a></span>

A memento object that stores state in the context of the currently opened [workspace](#workspace.workspaceFolders).

### <span id="FileSystem"></span><span id="1829" class="code-item">FileSystem</span>

The file system interface exposes the editor's built-in and contributed [file system providers](#FileSystemProvider). It allows extensions to work with files from the local disk as well as files from remote places, like the remote extension host or ftp-servers.

_Note_ that an instance of this interface is available as [`workspace.fs`](#workspace.fs).

### <span id="FileSystemError"></span><span id="1746" class="code-item">FileSystemError</span>

### <span id="FileSystemProvider"></span><span id="1780" class="code-item">FileSystemProvider</span>

The filesystem provider defines what the editor needs to read, write, discover, and to manage files and folders. It allows extensions to serve files from remote places, like ftp-servers, and to seamlessly integrate those into the editor.

- _Note 1:_ The filesystem provider API works with [uris](#Uri) and assumes hierarchical paths, e.g. `foo:/my/path` is a child of `foo:/my/` and a parent of `foo:/my/path/deeper`.
- _Note 2:_ There is an activation event `onFileSystem:<scheme>` that fires when a file or folder is being accessed.
- _Note 3:_ The word ‘file’ is often used to denote all [kinds](#FileType) of files, e.g. folders, symbolic links, and regular files.

#### Events

<span id="FileSystemProvider.onDidChangeFile"></span><span id="1781" class="ts" data-target="#details-1781" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidChangeFile</span>: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<a href="#FileChangeEvent" class="type-ref">FileChangeEvent</a>\[\]&gt;</span>

An event to signal that a resource has been created, changed, or deleted. This event should fire for resources that are being [watched](#FileSystemProvider.watch) by clients of this provider.

_Note:_ It is important that the metadata of the file that changed provides an updated `mtime` that advanced from the previous value in the [stat](#FileStat) and a correct `size` value. Otherwise there may be optimizations in place that will not show the change in an editor for example.

#### Methods

<span id="FileSystemProvider.copy"></span><span id="1823" class="ts" data-target="#details-1823" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">copy</span>(<span class="ident">source</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, <span class="ident">destination</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, <span class="ident">options</span>: {overwrite: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span>}): <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span> | <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

Copy files or folders. Implementing this function is optional but it will speedup the copy operation.

- _throws_ - [`FileNotFound`](#FileSystemError.FileNotFound) when `source` doesn't exist.

<!-- -->

- _throws_ - [`FileNotFound`](#FileSystemError.FileNotFound) when parent of `destination` doesn't exist, e.g. no mkdirp-logic required.

<!-- -->

- _throws_ - [`FileExists`](#FileSystemError.FileExists) when `destination` exists and when the `overwrite` option is not `true`.

<!-- -->

- _throws_ - [`NoPermissions`](#FileSystemError.NoPermissions) when permissions aren't sufficient.

### <span id="FileSystemWatcher"></span><span id="472" class="code-item">FileSystemWatcher</span>

A file system watcher notifies about changes to files and folders on disk or from other [FileSystemProviders](#FileSystemProvider).

To get an instance of a `FileSystemWatcher` use [createFileSystemWatcher](#workspace.createFileSystemWatcher).

#### Events

An event which fires on file/folder creation.

### <span id="FileWillCreateEvent"></span><span id="2283" class="code-item">FileWillCreateEvent</span>

An event that is fired when files are going to be created.

To make modifications to the workspace before the files are created, call the [\`waitUntil](#FileWillCreateEvent.waitUntil)-function with a thenable that resolves to a [workspace edit](#WorkspaceEdit).

#### Properties

<span id="FileWillCreateEvent.files"></span><span id="2284" class="ts" data-target="#details-2284" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">files</span>: <a href="#ReadonlyArray" class="type-ref">ReadonlyArray</a>&lt;<a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>&gt;</span>

The files that are going to be created.

#### Methods

<span id="FileWillCreateEvent.waitUntil"></span><span id="2286" class="ts" data-target="#details-2286" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">waitUntil</span>(<span class="ident">thenable</span>: <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<a href="#WorkspaceEdit" class="type-ref">WorkspaceEdit</a>&gt;): <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span>

Allows to pause the event and to apply a [workspace edit](#WorkspaceEdit).

_Note:_ This function can only be called during event dispatch and not in an asynchronous manner:

    workspace.onWillCreateFiles(event => {
        // async, will *throw* an error
        setTimeout(() => event.waitUntil(promise));

        // sync, OK
        event.waitUntil(promise);
    })

### <span id="GlobPattern"></span><span id="2628" class="code-item">GlobPattern</span>

A file glob pattern to match file paths against. This can either be a glob pattern string (like `**/.{ts,js}` or `.{ts,js}`) or a [relative pattern](#RelativePattern).

Glob patterns can have the following syntax:

- `*` to match one or more characters in a path segment
- `?` to match on one character in a path segment
- `**` to match any number of path segments, including none
- `{}` to group conditions (e.g. `**/*.{ts,js}` matches all TypeScript and JavaScript files)
- `[]` to declare a range of characters to match in a path segment (e.g., `example.[0-9]` to match on `example.0`, `example.1`, …)
- `[!…]` to negate a range of characters to match in a path segment (e.g., `example.[!0-9]` to match on `example.a`, `example.b`, but not `example.0`)

Note: a backslash (`</code>) is not valid within a glob pattern. If you have an existing file path to match against, consider to use the relative pattern support that takes care of converting any backslash into slash. Otherwise, make sure to convert any backslash to slash when creating the glob pattern. `

<span id="GlobPattern"></span><span id="2628" class="ts" data-target="#details-2628" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">GlobPattern</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <a href="#RelativePattern" class="type-ref">RelativePattern</a></span>

### <span id="InputBox"></span><span id="2230" class="code-item">InputBox</span>

A concrete [QuickInput](#QuickInput) to let the user input a text value.

Note that in many cases the more convenient [window.showInputBox](#window.showInputBox) is easier to use. [window.createInputBox](#window.createInputBox) should be used when [window.showInputBox](#window.showInputBox) does not offer the required flexibility.

#### Events

<span id="InputBox.onDidHide"></span><span id="2250" class="ts" data-target="#details-2250" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidHide</span>: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

An event signaling when this input UI is hidden.

There are several reasons why this UI might have to be hidden and the extension will be notified through [QuickInput.onDidHide](#QuickInput.onDidHide). (Examples include: an explicit call to [QuickInput.hide](#QuickInput.hide), the user pressing Esc, some other input UI opening, etc.)

Set to `true` to keep the input box open when focus moves to another part of the editor or to another window.

<span id="InputBoxOptions.prompt"></span><span id="542" class="ts" data-target="#details-542" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">prompt</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

<span id="InputBoxOptions.valueSelection"></span><span id="541" class="ts" data-target="#details-541" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">valueSelection</span>?: \[<span class="type-intrinsic">number</span>, <span class="type-intrinsic">number</span>\]</span>

When `undefined` the whole word will be selected, when empty (start equals end) only the cursor will be set, otherwise the defined range will be selected.

### <span id="MarkdownString"></span><span id="661" class="code-item">MarkdownString</span>

The MarkdownString represents human-readable text that supports formatting via the markdown syntax. Standard markdown is supported, also tables, but no embedded html.

When created with `supportThemeIcons` then rendering of [theme icons](#ThemeIcon) via the `$(<name>)`-syntax is supported.

### <span id="MarkedString"></span><span id="2635" class="code-item">MarkedString</span>

MarkedString can be used to render human-readable text. It is either a markdown string or a code-block that provides a language and a code snippet. Note that markdown strings will be sanitized - that means html will be escaped.

### <span id="OpenDialogOptions"></span><span id="515" class="code-item">OpenDialogOptions</span>

Options to configure the behaviour of a file open dialog.

- Note 1: A dialog can select files, folders, or both. This is not true for Windows which enforces to open either files or folder, but _not both_.
- Note 2: Explicitly setting `canSelectFiles` and `canSelectFolders` to `false` is futile and the editor then silently adjusts the options to select files.

#### Properties

<span id="OpenDialogOptions.canSelectFiles"></span><span id="518" class="ts" data-target="#details-518" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">canSelectFiles</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Allow to select files, defaults to `true`.

<span id="OpenDialogOptions.canSelectFolders"></span><span id="519" class="ts" data-target="#details-519" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">canSelectFolders</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Allow to select folders, defaults to `false`.

<span id="OpenDialogOptions.canSelectMany"></span><span id="520" class="ts" data-target="#details-520" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">canSelectMany</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Allow to select many files or folders.

<span id="OpenDialogOptions.defaultUri"></span><span id="516" class="ts" data-target="#details-516" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">defaultUri</span>?: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

The resource the dialog shows when opened.

<span id="OpenDialogOptions.filters"></span><span id="521" class="ts" data-target="#details-521" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">filters</span>?: </span>

A set of file filters that are used by the dialog. Each entry is a human-readable label, like “TypeScript”, and an array of extensions, e.g.

    {
        'Images': ['png', 'jpg']
        'TypeScript': ['ts', 'tsx']
    }

<span id="OpenDialogOptions.openLabel"></span><span id="517" class="ts" data-target="#details-517" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">openLabel</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A human-readable string for the open button.

<span id="OpenDialogOptions.title"></span><span id="525" class="ts" data-target="#details-525" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">title</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Dialog title.

This parameter might be ignored, as not all operating systems display a title on open dialogs (for example, macOS).

### <span id="ProviderResult"></span><span id="2630" class="code-item">ProviderResult&lt;T&gt;</span>

A provider result represents the values a provider, like the [`HoverProvider`](#HoverProvider), may return. For once this is the actual result type `T`, like `Hover`, or a thenable that resolves to that type `T`. In addition, `null` and `undefined` can be returned - either directly or from a thenable.

The snippets below are all valid implementations of the [`HoverProvider`](#HoverProvider):

    let a: HoverProvider = {
        provideHover(doc, pos, token): ProviderResult<Hover> {
            return new Hover('Hello World');
        }
    }

    let b: HoverProvider = {
        provideHover(doc, pos, token): ProviderResult<Hover> {
            return new Promise(resolve => {
                resolve(new Hover('Hello World'));
             });
        }
    }

    let c: HoverProvider = {
        provideHover(doc, pos, token): ProviderResult<Hover> {
            return; // undefined
        }
    }

<span id="ProviderResult"></span><span id="2630" class="ts" data-target="#details-2630" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">ProviderResult</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">null</span> | <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">null</span>&gt;</span>

### <span id="Pseudoterminal"></span><span id="2119" class="code-item">Pseudoterminal</span>

Defines the interface of a terminal pty, enabling extensions to control a terminal.

#### Events

<span id="Pseudoterminal.onDidClose"></span><span id="2122" class="ts" data-target="#details-2122" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidClose</span>?: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">number</span>&gt;</span>

An event that when fired will signal that the pty is closed and dispose of the terminal.

A number can be used to provide an exit code for the terminal. Exit codes must be positive and a non-zero exit codes signals failure which shows a notification for a regular terminal and allows dependent tasks to proceed when used with the `CustomExecution` API.

**Example:** Exit the terminal when “y” is pressed, otherwise show a notification.

    const writeEmitter = new vscode.EventEmitter<string>();
    const closeEmitter = new vscode.EventEmitter<vscode.TerminalDimensions>();
    const pty: vscode.Pseudoterminal = {
      onDidWrite: writeEmitter.event,
      onDidClose: closeEmitter.event,
      open: () => writeEmitter.fire('Press y to exit successfully'),
      close: () => {},
      handleInput: data => {
        if (data !== 'y') {
          vscode.window.showInformationMessage('Something went wrong');
        }
        closeEmitter.fire();
      }
    };
    vscode.window.createTerminal({ name: 'Exit example', pty });

<span id="Pseudoterminal.onDidOverrideDimensions"></span><span id="2121" class="ts" data-target="#details-2121" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidOverrideDimensions</span>?: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<a href="#TerminalDimensions" class="type-ref">TerminalDimensions</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span>&gt;</span>

An event that when fired allows overriding the [dimensions](#Pseudoterminal.setDimensions) of the terminal. Note that when set, the overridden dimensions will only take effect when they are lower than the actual dimensions of the terminal (ie. there will never be a scroll bar). Set to `undefined` for the terminal to go back to the regular dimensions (fit to the size of the panel).

**Example:** Override the dimensions of a terminal to 20 columns and 10 rows

    const dimensionsEmitter = new vscode.EventEmitter<vscode.TerminalDimensions>();
    const pty: vscode.Pseudoterminal = {
      onDidWrite: writeEmitter.event,
      onDidOverrideDimensions: dimensionsEmitter.event,
      open: () => {
        dimensionsEmitter.fire({
          columns: 20,
          rows: 10
        });
      },
      close: () => {}
    };
    vscode.window.createTerminal({ name: 'My terminal', pty });

<span id="Pseudoterminal.onDidWrite"></span><span id="2120" class="ts" data-target="#details-2120" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidWrite</span>: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>&gt;</span>

An event that when fired will write data to the terminal. Unlike [Terminal.sendText](#Terminal.sendText) which sends text to the underlying child pseudo-device (the child), this will write the text to parent pseudo-device (the _terminal_ itself).

Note writing ``will just move the cursor down 1 row, you need to write`/code> as well to move the cursor to the left-most cell. `

**Example:** Write red text to the terminal

    const writeEmitter = new vscode.EventEmitter<string>();
    const pty: vscode.Pseudoterminal = {
      onDidWrite: writeEmitter.event,
      open: () => writeEmitter.fire('\x1b[31mHello world\x1b[0m'),
      close: () => {}
    };
    vscode.window.createTerminal({ name: 'My terminal', pty });

**Example:** Move the cursor to the 10th row and 20th column and write an asterisk

    writeEmitter.fire('\x1b[10;20H*');

#### Methods

<span id="Pseudoterminal.close"></span><span id="2127" class="ts" data-target="#details-2127" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">close</span>(): <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span>

Implement to handle when the terminal is closed by an act of the user.

<span id="Pseudoterminal.handleInput"></span><span id="2129" class="ts" data-target="#details-2129" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">handleInput</span>(<span class="ident">data</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>): <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span>

Implement to handle incoming keystrokes in the terminal or when an extension calls [Terminal.sendText](#Terminal.sendText). `data` contains the keystrokes/text serialized into their corresponding VT sequence representation.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="data"></span><span id="2130" class="ts" data-target="#details-2130" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">data</span><span>: </span><span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The incoming data.</p><p><strong>Example:</strong> Echo input in the terminal. The sequence for enter (<code>/code&gt;) is translated to CRLF to go to a new line and move the cursor to the start of the line. </code></p><pre><code>const writeEmitter = new vscode.EventEmitter&lt;string&gt;();
const pty: vscode.Pseudoterminal = {
  onDidWrite: writeEmitter.event,
  open: () =&gt; {},
  close: () =&gt; {},
  handleInput: data =&gt; writeEmitter.fire(data === &#39;\r&#39; ? &#39;\r\n&#39; : data)
};
vscode.window.createTerminal({ name: &#39;Local echo&#39;, pty });</code></pre></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

Implement to handle when the pty is open and ready to start firing events.

<span id="Pseudoterminal.setDimensions"></span><span id="2132" class="ts" data-target="#details-2132" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">setDimensions</span>(<span class="ident">dimensions</span>: <a href="#TerminalDimensions" class="type-ref">TerminalDimensions</a>): <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span>

Implement to handle when the number of rows and columns that fit into the terminal panel changes, for example when font size changes or when the panel is resized. The initial state of a terminal's dimensions should be treated as `undefined` until this is triggered as the size of a terminal isn't know until it shows up in the user interface.

When dimensions are overridden by [onDidOverrideDimensions](#Pseudoterminal.onDidOverrideDimensions), `setDimensions` will continue to be called with the regular panel dimensions, allowing the extension continue to react dimension changes.

### <span id="QuickInput"></span><span id="2187" class="code-item">QuickInput</span>

A light-weight user input UI that is initially not visible. After configuring it through its properties the extension can make it visible by calling [QuickInput.show](#QuickInput.show).

There are several reasons why this UI might have to be hidden and the extension will be notified through [QuickInput.onDidHide](#QuickInput.onDidHide). (Examples include: an explicit call to [QuickInput.hide](#QuickInput.hide), the user pressing Esc, some other input UI opening, etc.)

A user pressing Enter or some other gesture implying acceptance of the current state does not automatically hide this UI component. It is up to the extension to decide whether to accept the user's input and if the UI should indeed be hidden through a call to [QuickInput.hide](#QuickInput.hide).

When the extension no longer needs this input UI, it should [QuickInput.dispose](#QuickInput.dispose) it to allow for freeing up any resources associated with it.

See [QuickPick](#QuickPick) and [InputBox](#InputBox) for concrete UIs.

#### Events

<span id="QuickInput.onDidHide"></span><span id="2198" class="ts" data-target="#details-2198" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidHide</span>: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

An event signaling when this input UI is hidden.

There are several reasons why this UI might have to be hidden and the extension will be notified through [QuickInput.onDidHide](#QuickInput.onDidHide). (Examples include: an explicit call to [QuickInput.hide](#QuickInput.hide), the user pressing Esc, some other input UI opening, etc.)

#### Properties

Change this to true, e.g., while loading more data or validating user input.

If the UI should allow for user input. Defaults to true.

Change this to false, e.g., while validating user input or loading data for the next step in user input.

<span id="QuickInput.ignoreFocusOut"></span><span id="2193" class="ts" data-target="#details-2193" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">ignoreFocusOut</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

### <span id="QuickPick"></span><span id="2201" class="code-item">QuickPick&lt;T&gt;</span>

A concrete [QuickInput](#QuickInput) to let the user pick an item from a list of items of type T. The items can be filtered through a filter text field and there is an option [canSelectMany](#QuickPick.canSelectMany) to allow for selecting multiple items.

Note that in many cases the more convenient [window.showQuickPick](#window.showQuickPick) is easier to use. [window.createQuickPick](#window.createQuickPick) should be used when [window.showQuickPick](#window.showQuickPick) does not offer the required flexibility.

### <span id="Range"></span><span id="117" class="code-item">Range</span>

A range represents an ordered pair of two positions. It is guaranteed that [start](#Range.start).isBeforeOrEqual([end](#Range.end))

Range objects are **immutable**. Use the [with](#Range.with), [intersection](#Range.intersection), or [union](#Range.union) methods to derive new ranges from an existing range.

#### Constructors

<span id="Range.new Range"></span><span id="121" class="ts" data-target="#details-121" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">new Range</span>(<span class="ident">start</span>: <a href="#Position" class="type-ref">Position</a>, <span class="ident">end</span>: <a href="#Position" class="type-ref">Position</a>): <a href="#Range" class="type-ref">Range</a></span>

Create a new range from two positions. If `start` is not before or equal to `end`, the values will be swapped.

### <span id="RelativePattern"></span><span id="549" class="code-item">RelativePattern</span>

A relative pattern is a helper to construct glob patterns that are matched relatively to a base path. The base path can either be an absolute file path or a [workspace folder](#WorkspaceFolder).

#### Constructors

<span id="RelativePattern.new RelativePattern"></span><span id="553" class="ts" data-target="#details-553" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">new RelativePattern</span>(<span class="ident">base</span>: <a href="#WorkspaceFolder" class="type-ref">WorkspaceFolder</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, <span class="ident">pattern</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>): <a href="#RelativePattern" class="type-ref">RelativePattern</a></span>

Creates a new relative pattern object with a base path and pattern to match. This pattern will be matched on file paths relative to the base path.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="base"></span><span id="554" class="ts" data-target="#details-554" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">base</span><span>: </span><a href="#WorkspaceFolder" class="type-ref">WorkspaceFolder</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A base file path to which this pattern will be matched against relatively.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span id="pattern"></span><span id="555" class="ts" data-target="#details-555" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">pattern</span><span>: </span><span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A file glob pattern like <code>*.{ts,js}</code> that will be matched on file paths relative to the base path.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#RelativePattern" class="type-ref">RelativePattern</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

#### Properties

<span id="RelativePattern.base"></span><span id="550" class="ts" data-target="#details-550" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">base</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A base file path to which this pattern will be matched against relatively.

<span id="RelativePattern.pattern"></span><span id="551" class="ts" data-target="#details-551" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">pattern</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A file glob pattern like `*.{ts,js}` that will be matched on file paths relative to the base path.

Example: Given a base of `/home/work/folder` and a file path of `/home/work/folder/index.js`, the file glob pattern will match on `index.js`.

### <span id="RenameProvider"></span><span id="925" class="code-item">RenameProvider</span>

The rename provider interface defines the contract between extensions and the [rename](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/editingevolved#_rename-symbol)-feature.

#### Methods

<span id="RenameProvider.prepareRename"></span><span id="933" class="ts" data-target="#details-933" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">prepareRename</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <a href="#TextDocument" class="type-ref">TextDocument</a>, <span class="ident">position</span>: <a href="#Position" class="type-ref">Position</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#Range" class="type-ref">Range</a> | {placeholder: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, range: <a href="#Range" class="type-ref">Range</a>}&gt;</span>

Optional function for resolving and validating a position _before_ running rename. The result can be a range or a range and a placeholder text. The placeholder text should be the identifier of the symbol which is being renamed - when omitted the text in the returned range is used.

_Note:_ This function should throw an error or return a rejected thenable when the provided location doesn't allow for a rename.

The lack of a result can signaled by returning <code>undefined</code> or <code>null</code>.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="RenameProvider.provideRenameEdits"></span><span id="927" class="ts" data-target="#details-927" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">provideRenameEdits</span>(<span class="ident">document</span>: <a href="#TextDocument" class="type-ref">TextDocument</a>, <span class="ident">position</span>: <a href="#Position" class="type-ref">Position</a>, <span class="ident">newName</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<a href="#WorkspaceEdit" class="type-ref">WorkspaceEdit</a>&gt;</span>

Provide an edit that describes changes that have to be made to one or many resources to rename a symbol to a different name.

#### Methods

### <span id="SnippetString"></span><span id="896" class="code-item">SnippetString</span>

A snippet string is a template which allows to insert text and to control the editor cursor when insertion happens.

A snippet can define tab stops and placeholders with `$1`, `2 < /code > and < code>{3:foo}`. `0 < /code > definesthefinaltabstop, itdefaultstotheendofthesnippet.Variablesaredefinedwith < code>name` and `${name:default value}`. The full snippet syntax is documented [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/userdefinedsnippets#_creating-your-own-snippets).

<span id="SourceControlResourceState.contextValue"></span><span id="2350" class="ts" data-target="#details-2350" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">contextValue</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Context value of the resource state. This can be used to contribute resource specific actions. For example, if a resource is given a context value as `diffable`. When contributing actions to `scm/resourceState/context` using `menus` extension point, you can specify context value for key `scmResourceState` in `when` expressions, like `scmResourceState == diffable`.

        "contributes": {
            "menus": {
                "scm/resourceState/context": [
                    {
                        "command": "extension.diff",
                        "when": "scmResourceState == diffable"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }

This will show action `extension.diff` only for resources with `contextValue` is `diffable`.

<span id="SourceControlResourceState.decorations"></span><span id="2349" class="ts" data-target="#details-2349" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">decorations</span>?: <a href="#SourceControlResourceDecorations" class="type-ref">SourceControlResourceDecorations</a></span>

A status bar item is a status bar contribution that can show text and icons and run a command on click.

#### Properties

<span id="StatusBarItem.accessibilityInformation"></span><span id="1485" class="ts" data-target="#details-1485" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">accessibilityInformation</span>?: <a href="#AccessibilityInformation" class="type-ref">AccessibilityInformation</a></span>

The alignment of this item.

<span id="StatusBarItem.color"></span><span id="1483" class="ts" data-target="#details-1483" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">color</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <a href="#ThemeColor" class="type-ref">ThemeColor</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span>
