<span id="StatusBarItem.command"></span><span id="1484" class="ts" data-target="#details-1484" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">command</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <a href="#Command" class="type-ref">Command</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span>

[`Command`](#Command) or identifier of a command to run on click.

The command must be [known](#commands.getCommands).

Note that if this is a [`Command`](#Command) object, only the [`command`](#Command.command) and [`arguments`](#Command.arguments) are used by VS Code.

<span id="StatusBarItem.priority"></span><span id="1480" class="ts" data-target="#details-1480" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">priority</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">number</span></span>

<span id="StatusBarItem.text"></span><span id="1481" class="ts" data-target="#details-1481" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">text</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

The text to show for the entry. You can embed icons in the text by leveraging the syntax:

`My text $(icon-name) contains icons like $(icon-name) this one.`

Where the icon-name is taken from the [codicon](https://microsoft.github.io/vscode-codicons/dist/codicon.html) icon set, e.g. `light-bulb`, `thumbsup`, `zap` etc.

### <span id="TaskDefinition"></span><span id="1614" class="code-item">TaskDefinition</span>

A structure that defines a task kind in the system. The value must be JSON-stringifyable.

#### Properties

<span id="TaskDefinition.type"></span><span id="1615" class="ts" data-target="#details-1615" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">type</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

The task definition describing the task provided by an extension. Usually a task provider defines more properties to identify a task. They need to be defined in the package.json of the extension under the ‘taskDefinitions’ extension point. The npm task definition for example looks like this

    interface NpmTaskDefinition extends TaskDefinition {
        script: string;
    }

Note that type identifier starting with a ‘$’ are reserved for internal usages and shouldn't be used by extensions.

### <span id="TaskProvider"></span><span id="1710" class="code-item">TaskProvider&lt;T&gt;</span>

A task provider allows to add tasks to the task service. A task provider is registered via \#tasks.registerTaskProvider.

#### Methods

Provides tasks.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="token"></span><span id="1714" class="ts" data-target="#details-1714" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">token</span><span>: </span><a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A cancellation token.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>[]&gt;</span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>an array of tasks</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="TaskProvider.resolveTask"></span><span id="1716" class="ts" data-target="#details-1716" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">resolveTask</span>(<span class="ident">task</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>&gt;</span>

Resolves a task that has no [`execution`](#Task.execution) set. Tasks are often created from information found in the `tasks.json`-file. Such tasks miss the information on how to execute them and a task provider must fill in the missing information in the `resolveTask`-method. This method will not be called for tasks returned from the above `provideTasks` method since those tasks are always fully resolved. A valid default implementation for the `resolveTask` method is to return `undefined`.

          vscode.window.showInformationMessage(`Exit code: ${t.exitStatus.code}`);
      }
    });

### <span id="TerminalOptions"></span><span id="2105" class="code-item">TerminalOptions</span>

Value-object describing what options a terminal should use.

#### Properties

<span id="TerminalOptions.cwd"></span><span id="2109" class="ts" data-target="#details-2109" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">cwd</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

A path or Uri for the current working directory to be used for the terminal.

<span id="TerminalOptions.env"></span><span id="2110" class="ts" data-target="#details-2110" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">env</span>?: </span>

Object with environment variables that will be added to the VS Code process.

<span id="TerminalOptions.hideFromUser"></span><span id="2115" class="ts" data-target="#details-2115" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">hideFromUser</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

When enabled the terminal will run the process as normal but not be surfaced to the user until `Terminal.show` is called. The typical usage for this is when you need to run something that may need interactivity but only want to tell the user about it when interaction is needed. Note that the terminals will still be exposed to all extensions as normal.

<span id="TerminalOptions.name"></span><span id="2106" class="ts" data-target="#details-2106" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">name</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A human-readable string which will be used to represent the terminal in the UI.

<span id="TerminalOptions.shellArgs"></span><span id="2108" class="ts" data-target="#details-2108" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">shellArgs</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>\[\] | <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Args for the custom shell executable. A string can be used on Windows only which allows specifying shell args in [command-line format](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-au/08dfcab2-eb6e-49a4-80eb-87d4076c98c6).

<span id="TerminalOptions.shellPath"></span><span id="2107" class="ts" data-target="#details-2107" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">shellPath</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A path to a custom shell executable to be used in the terminal.

<span id="TerminalOptions.strictEnv"></span><span id="2114" class="ts" data-target="#details-2114" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">strictEnv</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Whether the terminal process environment should be exactly as provided in `TerminalOptions.env`. When this is false (default), the environment will be based on the window's environment and also apply configured platform settings like `terminal.integrated.windows.env` on top. When this is true, the complete environment must be provided as nothing will be inherited from the process or any configuration.

### <span id="TextDocument"></span><span id="38" class="code-item">TextDocument</span>

Represents a text document, such as a source file. Text documents have [lines](#TextLine) and knowledge about an underlying resource like a file.

#### Properties

<span id="TextDocument.eol"></span><span id="48" class="ts" data-target="#details-48" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">eol</span>: <a href="#EndOfLine" class="type-ref">EndOfLine</a></span>

The [end of line](#EndOfLine) sequence that is predominately used in this document.

<span id="TextDocument.fileName"></span><span id="40" class="ts" data-target="#details-40" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">fileName</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

The file system path of the associated resource. Shorthand notation for [TextDocument.uri.fsPath](#TextDocument.uri). Independent of the uri scheme.

<span id="TextDocument.isClosed"></span><span id="45" class="ts" data-target="#details-45" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">isClosed</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

`true` if the document has been closed. A closed document isn't synchronized anymore and won't be re-used when the same resource is opened again.

<span id="TextDocument.isDirty"></span><span id="44" class="ts" data-target="#details-44" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">isDirty</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

`true` if there are unpersisted changes.

<span id="TextDocument.isUntitled"></span><span id="41" class="ts" data-target="#details-41" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">isUntitled</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Is this document representing an untitled file which has never been saved yet. _Note_ that this does not mean the document will be saved to disk, use [`uri.scheme`](#Uri.scheme) to figure out where a document will be [saved](#FileSystemProvider), e.g. `file`, `ftp` etc.

<span id="TextDocument.languageId"></span><span id="42" class="ts" data-target="#details-42" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">languageId</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

The identifier of the language associated with this document.

<span id="TextDocument.lineCount"></span><span id="49" class="ts" data-target="#details-49" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">lineCount</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">number</span></span>

The number of lines in this document.

<span id="TextDocument.uri"></span><span id="39" class="ts" data-target="#details-39" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">uri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

The associated uri for this document.

_Note_ that most documents use the `file`-scheme, which means they are files on disk. However, **not** all documents are saved on disk and therefore the `scheme` must be checked before trying to access the underlying file or siblings on disk.

- _see_ - [FileSystemProvider](#FileSystemProvider)

<span id="TextDocument.version"></span><span id="43" class="ts" data-target="#details-43" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">version</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">number</span></span>

The version number of this document (it will strictly increase after each change, including undo/redo).

Get the text of this document. A substring can be retrieved by providing a range. The range will be [adjusted](#TextDocument.validateRange).

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="range"></span><span id="63" class="ts" data-target="#details-63" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">range</span><span>?</span><span>: </span><a href="#Range" class="type-ref">Range</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>Include only the text included by the range.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>The text inside the provided range or the entire text.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="TextDocument.getWordRangeAtPosition"></span><span id="65" class="ts" data-target="#details-65" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">getWordRangeAtPosition</span>(<span class="ident">position</span>: <a href="#Position" class="type-ref">Position</a>, <span class="ident">regex</span>?: <a href="#RegExp" class="type-ref">RegExp</a>): <a href="#Range" class="type-ref">Range</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span>

Get a word-range at the given position. By default words are defined by common separators, like space, -, \_, etc. In addition, per language custom [word definitions](#LanguageConfiguration.wordPattern) can be defined. It is also possible to provide a custom regular expression.

- _Note 1:_ A custom regular expression must not match the empty string and if it does, it will be ignored.
- _Note 2:_ A custom regular expression will fail to match multiline strings and in the name of speed regular expressions should not match words with spaces. Use [`TextLine.text`](#TextLine.text) for more complex, non-wordy, scenarios.

The position will be [adjusted](#TextDocument.validatePosition).

### <span id="TextDocumentContentProvider"></span><span id="491" class="code-item">TextDocumentContentProvider</span>

A text document content provider allows to add readonly documents to the editor, such as source from a dll or generated html from md.

Content providers are [registered](#workspace.registerTextDocumentContentProvider) for a [uri-scheme](#Uri.scheme). When a uri with that scheme is to be [loaded](#workspace.openTextDocument) the content provider is asked.

#### Events

<span id="TextDocumentContentProvider.onDidChange"></span><span id="492" class="ts" data-target="#details-492" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidChange</span>?: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>&gt;</span>

An event to signal a resource has changed.

#### Methods

<span id="TextDocumentContentProvider.provideTextDocumentContent"></span><span id="494" class="ts" data-target="#details-494" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">provideTextDocumentContent</span>(<span class="ident">uri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>&gt;</span>

Provide textual content for a given uri.

The editor will use the returned string-content to create a readonly [document](#TextDocument). Resources allocated should be released when the corresponding document has been [closed](#workspace.onDidCloseTextDocument).

**Note**: The contents of the created [document](#TextDocument) might not be identical to the provided text due to end-of-line-sequence normalization.

#### Properties

<span id="TextDocumentShowOptions.selection"></span><span id="246" class="ts" data-target="#details-246" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">selection</span>?: <a href="#Range" class="type-ref">Range</a></span>

The default is the [active](#ViewColumn.Active), other values are adjusted to be `Min(column, columnCount + 1)`, the [active](#ViewColumn.Active)-column is not adjusted. Use [`ViewColumn.Beside`](#ViewColumn.Beside) to open the editor to the side of the currently active one.

### <span id="TextDocumentWillSaveEvent"></span><span id="2275" class="code-item">TextDocumentWillSaveEvent</span>

An event that is fired when a [document](#TextDocument) will be saved.

To make modifications to the document before it is being saved, call the [`waitUntil`](#TextDocumentWillSaveEvent.waitUntil)-function with a thenable that resolves to an array of [text edits](#TextEdit).

#### Properties

<span id="TextDocumentWillSaveEvent.document"></span><span id="2276" class="ts" data-target="#details-2276" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">document</span>: <a href="#TextDocument" class="type-ref">TextDocument</a></span>

The document that will be saved.

<span id="TextDocumentWillSaveEvent.reason"></span><span id="2277" class="ts" data-target="#details-2277" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">reason</span>: <a href="#TextDocumentSaveReason" class="type-ref">TextDocumentSaveReason</a></span>

The reason why save was triggered.

#### Methods

<span id="TextDocumentWillSaveEvent.waitUntil"></span><span id="2279" class="ts" data-target="#details-2279" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">waitUntil</span>(<span class="ident">thenable</span>: <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<a href="#TextEdit" class="type-ref">TextEdit</a>\[\]&gt;): <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span>

Allows to pause the event loop and to apply [pre-save-edits](#TextEdit). Edits of subsequent calls to this function will be applied in order. The edits will be _ignored_ if concurrent modifications of the document happened.

_Note:_ This function can only be called during event dispatch and not in an asynchronous manner:

    workspace.onWillSaveTextDocument(event => {
        // async, will *throw* an error
        setTimeout(() => event.waitUntil(promise));

        // sync, OK
        event.waitUntil(promise);
    })

### <span id="TextEditorEdit"></span><span id="379" class="code-item">TextEditorEdit</span>

A complex edit that will be applied in one transaction on a TextEditor. This holds a description of the edits and if the edits are valid (i.e. no overlapping regions, document was not changed in the meantime, etc.) they can be applied on a [document](#TextDocument) associated with a [text editor](#TextEditor).

#### Methods

<span id="TextEditorEdit.delete"></span><span id="389" class="ts" data-target="#details-389" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">delete</span>(<span class="ident">location</span>: <a href="#Range" class="type-ref">Range</a> | <a href="#Selection" class="type-ref">Selection</a>): <span class="type-intrinsic">void</span></span>

Delete a certain text region.

Insert text at a location. You can use or in `value` and they will be normalized to the current [document](#TextDocument). Although the equivalent text edit can be made with [replace](#TextEditorEdit.replace), `insert` will produce a different resulting selection (it will get moved).

### <span id="TextEditorOptions"></span><span id="218" class="code-item">TextEditorOptions</span>

Represents a [text editor](#TextEditor)'s [options](#TextEditor.options).

#### Properties

<span id="TextEditorOptions.cursorStyle"></span><span id="221" class="ts" data-target="#details-221" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">cursorStyle</span>?: <a href="#TextEditorCursorStyle" class="type-ref">TextEditorCursorStyle</a></span>

The rendering style of the cursor in this editor. When getting a text editor's options, this property will always be present. When setting a text editor's options, this property is optional.

<span id="TextEditorOptions.insertSpaces"></span><span id="220" class="ts" data-target="#details-220" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">insertSpaces</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

When pressing Tab insert [n](#TextEditorOptions.tabSize) spaces. When getting a text editor's options, this property will always be a boolean (resolved). When setting a text editor's options, this property is optional and it can be a boolean or `“auto”`.

<span id="TextEditorOptions.lineNumbers"></span><span id="222" class="ts" data-target="#details-222" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">lineNumbers</span>?: <a href="#TextEditorLineNumbersStyle" class="type-ref">TextEditorLineNumbersStyle</a></span>

Render relative line numbers w.r.t. the current line number. When getting a text editor's options, this property will always be present. When setting a text editor's options, this property is optional.

<span id="TextEditorOptions.tabSize"></span><span id="219" class="ts" data-target="#details-219" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">tabSize</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">number</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

The size in spaces a tab takes. This is used for two purposes:

- the rendering width of a tab character;
- the number of spaces to insert when [insertSpaces](#TextEditorOptions.insertSpaces) is true.

When getting a text editor's options, this property will always be a number (resolved). When setting a text editor's options, this property is optional and it can be a number or `“auto”`.

### <span id="ThemeIcon"></span><span id="251" class="code-item">ThemeIcon</span>

A reference to a named icon. Currently, [File](#ThemeIcon.File), [Folder](#ThemeIcon.Folder), and [codicons](https://microsoft.github.io/vscode-codicons/dist/codicon.html) are supported. Using a theme icon is preferred over a custom icon as it gives theme authors the possibility to change the icons.

_Note_ that theme icons can also be rendered inside labels and descriptions. Places that support theme icons spell this out and they use the `$(<name>)`-syntax, for instance `quickPick.label = “Hello World $(globe)”`.

Accessibility information used when screen reader interacts with this tree item. Generally, a TreeItem has no need to set the `role` of the accessibilityInformation; however, there are cases where a TreeItem is not displayed in a tree-like way where setting the `role` may make sense.

<span id="TreeItem.collapsibleState"></span><span id="2091" class="ts" data-target="#details-2091" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">collapsibleState</span>?: <a href="#TreeItemCollapsibleState" class="type-ref">TreeItemCollapsibleState</a></span>

<span id="TreeItem.command"></span><span id="2090" class="ts" data-target="#details-2090" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">command</span>?: <a href="#Command" class="type-ref">Command</a></span>

The [command](#Command) that should be executed when the tree item is selected.

<span id="TreeItem.contextValue"></span><span id="2092" class="ts" data-target="#details-2092" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">contextValue</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Context value of the tree item. This can be used to contribute item specific actions in the tree. For example, a tree item is given a context value as `folder`. When contributing actions to `view/item/context` using `menus` extension point, you can specify context value for key `viewItem` in `when` expression like `viewItem == folder`.

        "contributes": {
            "menus": {
                "view/item/context": [
                    {
                        "command": "extension.deleteFolder",
                        "when": "viewItem == folder"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }

This will show action `extension.deleteFolder` only for items with `contextValue` is `folder`.

<span id="TreeItem.description"></span><span id="2087" class="ts" data-target="#details-2087" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">description</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

A human-readable string which is rendered less prominent. When `true`, it is derived from [resourceUri](#TreeItem.resourceUri) and when `falsy`, it is not shown.

<span id="TreeItem.iconPath"></span><span id="2083" class="ts" data-target="#details-2083" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">iconPath</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a> | {dark: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, light: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>} | <a href="#ThemeIcon" class="type-ref">ThemeIcon</a></span>

The icon path or [ThemeIcon](#ThemeIcon) for the tree item. When `falsy`, [Folder Theme Icon](#ThemeIcon.Folder) is assigned, if item is collapsible otherwise [File Theme Icon](#ThemeIcon.File). When a file or folder [ThemeIcon](#ThemeIcon) is specified, icon is derived from the current file icon theme for the specified theme icon using [resourceUri](#TreeItem.resourceUri) (if provided).

<span id="TreeItem.id"></span><span id="2082" class="ts" data-target="#details-2082" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">id</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Optional id for the tree item that has to be unique across tree. The id is used to preserve the selection and expansion state of the tree item.

If not provided, an id is generated using the tree item's label. **Note** that when labels change, ids will change and that selection and expansion state cannot be kept stable anymore.

<span id="TreeItem.label"></span><span id="2081" class="ts" data-target="#details-2081" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">label</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A human-readable string describing this item. When `falsy`, it is derived from [resourceUri](#TreeItem.resourceUri).

<span id="TreeItem.resourceUri"></span><span id="2088" class="ts" data-target="#details-2088" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">resourceUri</span>?: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

The [uri](#Uri) of the resource representing this item.

Will be used to derive the [label](#TreeItem.label), when it is not provided. Will be used to derive the icon from current file icon theme, when [iconPath](#TreeItem.iconPath) has [ThemeIcon](#ThemeIcon) value.

<span id="TreeItem.tooltip"></span><span id="2089" class="ts" data-target="#details-2089" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">tooltip</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span>

The tooltip text when you hover over this item.

<span id="TreeView.reveal"></span><span id="2049" class="ts" data-target="#details-2049" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">reveal</span>(<span class="ident">element</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>, <span class="ident">options</span>?: {expand: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">number</span>, focus: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span>, select: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span>}): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

Reveals the given element in the tree view. If the tree view is not visible then the tree view is shown and element is revealed.

By default revealed element is selected. In order to not to select, set the option `select` to `false`. In order to focus, set the option `focus` to `true`. In order to expand the revealed element, set the option `expand` to `true`. To expand recursively set `expand` to the number of levels to expand. **NOTE:** You can expand only to 3 levels maximum.

**NOTE:** The [TreeDataProvider](#TreeDataProvider) that the `TreeView` [is registered with](#window.createTreeView) with must implement [getParent](#TreeDataProvider.getParent) method to access this API.

### <span id="Uri"></span><span id="394" class="code-item">Uri</span>

A universal resource identifier representing either a file on disk or another resource, like untitled resources.

#### Static

<span id="Uri.file"></span><span id="400" class="ts" data-target="#details-400" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">file</span>(<span class="ident">path</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>): <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

Create an URI from a file system path. The [scheme](#Uri.scheme) will be `file`.

The _difference_ between `Uri#parse` and `Uri#file` is that the latter treats the argument as path, not as stringified-uri. E.g. `Uri.file(path)` is _not_ the same as `Uri.parse(‘file://’ + path)` because the path might contain characters that are interpreted (\# and ?). See the following sample:

    const good = URI.file('/coding/c#/project1');
    good.scheme === 'file';
    good.path === '/coding/c#/project1';
    good.fragment === '';

    const bad = URI.parse('file://' + '/coding/c#/project1');
    bad.scheme === 'file';
    bad.path === '/coding/c'; // path is now broken
    bad.fragment === '/project1';

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="path"></span><span id="401" class="ts" data-target="#details-401" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">path</span><span>: </span><span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A file system or UNC path.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A new Uri instance.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="Uri.joinPath"></span><span id="403" class="ts" data-target="#details-403" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">joinPath</span>(<span class="ident">base</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, …<span class="ident">pathSegments</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>\[\]): <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

Create a new uri which path is the result of joining the path of the base uri with the provided path segments.

- Note 1: `joinPath` only affects the path component and all other components (scheme, authority, query, and fragment) are left as they are.
- Note 2: The base uri must have a path; an error is thrown otherwise.

The path segments are normalized in the following ways:

- sequences of path separators (`/` or `</code>) are replaced with a single separator `
- for `file`-uris on windows, the backslash-character (`</code>) is considered a path-separator `
- the `..`-segment denotes the parent segment, the `.` denotes the current segment
- paths have a root which always remains, for instance on windows drive-letters are roots so that is true: `joinPath(Uri.file(‘file:///c:/root’), ‘../../other’).fsPath === ‘c:/other’`

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="base"></span><span id="404" class="ts" data-target="#details-404" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">base</span><span>: </span><a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>An uri. Must have a path.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span id="pathSegments"></span><span id="405" class="ts" data-target="#details-405" data-toggle="collapse"><span>…</span><span class="ident">pathSegments</span><span>: </span><span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>[]</span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>One more more path fragments</p></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A new uri which path is joined with the given fragments</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="Uri.parse"></span><span id="396" class="ts" data-target="#details-396" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">parse</span>(<span class="ident">value</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, <span class="ident">strict</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span>): <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

Create an URI from a string, e.g. `http://www.msft.com/some/path`, `file:///usr/home`, or `scheme:with/path`.

_Note_ that for a while uris without a `scheme` were accepted. That is not correct as all uris should have a scheme. To avoid breakage of existing code the optional `strict`-argument has been added. We _strongly_ advise to use it, e.g. `Uri.parse(‘my:uri’, true)`

- _see_ - [Uri.toString](#Uri.toString)

Use the `file` and `parse` factory functions to create new `Uri` objects.

#### Properties

<span id="Uri.authority"></span><span id="414" class="ts" data-target="#details-414" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">authority</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Authority is the `www.msft.com` part of `http://www.msft.com/some/path?query#fragment`. The part between the first double slashes and the next slash.

<span id="Uri.fragment"></span><span id="417" class="ts" data-target="#details-417" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">fragment</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Fragment is the `fragment` part of `http://www.msft.com/some/path?query#fragment`.

<span id="Uri.fsPath"></span><span id="418" class="ts" data-target="#details-418" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">fsPath</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

The string representing the corresponding file system path of this Uri.

Will handle UNC paths and normalize windows drive letters to lower-case. Also uses the platform specific path separator.

- Will _not_ validate the path for invalid characters and semantics.
- Will _not_ look at the scheme of this Uri.
- The resulting string shall _not_ be used for display purposes but for disk operations, like `readFile` et al.

The _difference_ to the [`path`](#Uri.path)-property is the use of the platform specific path separator and the handling of UNC paths. The sample below outlines the difference:

    const u = URI.parse('file://server/c$/folder/file.txt')
    u.authority === 'server'
    u.path === '/shares/c$/file.txt'
    u.fsPath === '\\server\c$\folder\file.txt'

<span id="Uri.path"></span><span id="415" class="ts" data-target="#details-415" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">path</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Path is the `/some/path` part of `http://www.msft.com/some/path?query#fragment`.

<span id="Uri.query"></span><span id="416" class="ts" data-target="#details-416" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">query</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Query is the `query` part of `http://www.msft.com/some/path?query#fragment`.

<span id="Uri.scheme"></span><span id="413" class="ts" data-target="#details-413" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">scheme</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Scheme is the `http` part of `http://www.msft.com/some/path?query#fragment`. The part before the first colon.

#### Methods

<span id="Uri.toJSON"></span><span id="432" class="ts" data-target="#details-432" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">toJSON</span>(): <span class="type-intrinsic">any</span></span>

Returns a JSON representation of this Uri.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Returns</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><span class="type-intrinsic">any</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>An object.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="Uri.toString"></span><span id="429" class="ts" data-target="#details-429" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">toString</span>(<span class="ident">skipEncoding</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span>): <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Returns a string representation of this Uri. The representation and normalization of a URI depends on the scheme.

- The resulting string can be safely used with [Uri.parse](#Uri.parse).
- The resulting string shall _not_ be used for display purposes.

_Note_ that the implementation will encode _aggressive_ which often leads to unexpected, but not incorrect, results. For instance, colons are encoded to `%3A` which might be unexpected in file-uri. Also `&` and `=` will be encoded which might be unexpected for http-uris. For stability reasons this cannot be changed anymore. If you suffer from too aggressive encoding you should use the `skipEncoding`-argument: `uri.toString(true)`.

<table><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><thead><tr class="header"><th>Parameter</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td><span id="skipEncoding"></span><span id="430" class="ts" data-target="#details-430" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">skipEncoding</span><span>?</span><span>: </span><span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>Do not percentage-encode the result, defaults to <code>false</code>. Note that the <code>#</code> and <code>?</code> characters occurring in the path will always be encoded.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A string representation of this Uri.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="Uri.with"></span><span id="420" class="ts" data-target="#details-420" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">with</span>(<span class="ident">change</span>: {authority: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, fragment: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, path: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, query: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, scheme: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>}): <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

Derive a new Uri from this Uri.

    let file = Uri.parse('before:some/file/path');
    let other = file.with({ scheme: 'after' });
    assert.ok(other.toString() === 'after:some/file/path');

To unset components use <code>null</code> or the empty string.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>A new Uri that reflects the given change. ### <span id="Webview"></span><span id="1875" class="code-item">Webview</span>

Displays html content, similarly to an iframe.

#### Events

<span id="Webview.onDidReceiveMessage"></span><span id="1878" class="ts" data-target="#details-1878" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">onDidReceiveMessage</span>: <a href="#Event" class="type-ref">Event</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">any</span>&gt;</span>

Fired when the webview content posts a message.

Webview content can post strings or json serializable objects back to a VS Code extension. They cannot post `Blob`, `File`, `ImageData` and other DOM specific objects since the extension that receives the message does not run in a browser environment.

#### Properties

<span id="Webview.cspSource"></span><span id="1885" class="ts" data-target="#details-1885" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">cspSource</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

Content security policy source for webview resources.

This is the origin that should be used in a content security policy rule:

    img-src https: ${webview.cspSource} ...;

<span id="Webview.html"></span><span id="1877" class="ts" data-target="#details-1877" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">html</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

HTML contents of the webview.

This should be a complete, valid html document. Changing this property causes the webview to be reloaded.

Webviews are sandboxed from normal extension process, so all communication with the webview must use message passing. To send a message from the extension to the webview, use [`postMessage`](#Webview.postMessage). To send message from the webview back to an extension, use the `acquireVsCodeApi` function inside the webview to get a handle to VS Code's api and then call `.postMessage()`:

    <script>
        const vscode = acquireVsCodeApi(); // acquireVsCodeApi can only be invoked once
        vscode.postMessage({ message: 'hello!' });
    </script>

To load a resources from the workspace inside a webview, use the `asWebviewUri` method and ensure the resource's directory is listed in [`WebviewOptions.localResourceRoots`](#WebviewOptions.localResourceRoots).

Keep in mind that even though webviews are sandboxed, they still allow running scripts and loading arbitrary content, so extensions must follow all standard web security best practices when working with webviews. This includes properly sanitizing all untrusted input (including content from the workspace) and setting a [content security policy](https://aka.ms/vscode-api-webview-csp).

<span id="Webview.options"></span><span id="1876" class="ts" data-target="#details-1876" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">options</span>: <a href="#WebviewOptions" class="type-ref">WebviewOptions</a></span>

Content settings for the webview.

#### Methods

<span id="Webview.asWebviewUri"></span><span id="1883" class="ts" data-target="#details-1883" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">asWebviewUri</span>(<span class="ident">localResource</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>): <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

Convert a uri for the local file system to one that can be used inside webviews.

Webviews cannot directly load resources from the workspace or local file system using `file:` uris. The `asWebviewUri` function takes a local `file:` uri and converts it into a uri that can be used inside of a webview to load the same resource:

    webview.html = `<img src="${webview.asWebviewUri(vscode.Uri.file('/Users/codey/workspace/cat.gif'))}">`

### <span id="WebviewOptions"></span><span id="1870" class="code-item">WebviewOptions</span>

Content settings for a webview.

#### Properties

<span id="WebviewOptions.enableCommandUris"></span><span id="1872" class="ts" data-target="#details-1872" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">enableCommandUris</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Controls whether command uris are enabled in webview content or not.

Defaults to false.

<span id="WebviewOptions.enableScripts"></span><span id="1871" class="ts" data-target="#details-1871" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">enableScripts</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Controls whether scripts are enabled in the webview content or not.

Defaults to false (scripts-disabled).

<span id="WebviewOptions.localResourceRoots"></span><span id="1873" class="ts" data-target="#details-1873" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">localResourceRoots</span>?: <a href="#ReadonlyArray" class="type-ref">ReadonlyArray</a>&lt;<a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>&gt;</span>

Root paths from which the webview can load local (filesystem) resources using uris from `asWebviewUri`

Default to the root folders of the current workspace plus the extension's install directory.

Pass in an empty array to disallow access to any local resources.

<span id="WebviewOptions.portMapping"></span><span id="1874" class="ts" data-target="#details-1874" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">portMapping</span>?: <a href="#ReadonlyArray" class="type-ref">ReadonlyArray</a>&lt;<a href="#WebviewPortMapping" class="type-ref">WebviewPortMapping</a>&gt;</span>

Mappings of localhost ports used inside the webview.

Port mapping allow webviews to transparently define how localhost ports are resolved. This can be used to allow using a static localhost port inside the webview that is resolved to random port that a service is running on.

If a webview accesses localhost content, we recommend that you specify port mappings even if the `webviewPort` and `extensionHostPort` ports are the same.

_Note_ that port mappings only work for `http` or `https` urls. Websocket urls (e.g. `ws://localhost:3000`) cannot be mapped to another port.

### <span id="WebviewPanelOptions"></span><span id="1886" class="code-item">WebviewPanelOptions</span>

Content settings for a webview panel.

#### Properties

<span id="WebviewPanelOptions.enableFindWidget"></span><span id="1887" class="ts" data-target="#details-1887" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">enableFindWidget</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Controls if the find widget is enabled in the panel.

Defaults to false.

<span id="WebviewPanelOptions.retainContextWhenHidden"></span><span id="1888" class="ts" data-target="#details-1888" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">retainContextWhenHidden</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

Controls if the webview panel's content (iframe) is kept around even when the panel is no longer visible.

Normally the webview panel's html context is created when the panel becomes visible and destroyed when it is hidden. Extensions that have complex state or UI can set the `retainContextWhenHidden` to make VS Code keep the webview context around, even when the webview moves to a background tab. When a webview using `retainContextWhenHidden` becomes hidden, its scripts and other dynamic content are suspended. When the panel becomes visible again, the context is automatically restored in the exact same state it was in originally. You cannot send messages to a hidden webview, even with `retainContextWhenHidden` enabled.

`retainContextWhenHidden` has a high memory overhead and should only be used if your panel's context cannot be quickly saved and restored.

### <span id="WebviewPanelSerializer"></span><span id="1911" class="code-item">WebviewPanelSerializer&lt;T&gt;</span>

Restore webview panels that have been persisted when vscode shuts down.

There are two types of webview persistence:

- Persistence within a session.
- Persistence across sessions (across restarts of VS Code).

A `WebviewPanelSerializer` is only required for the second case: persisting a webview across sessions.

Persistence within a session allows a webview to save its state when it becomes hidden and restore its content from this state when it becomes visible again. It is powered entirely by the webview content itself. To save off a persisted state, call `acquireVsCodeApi().setState()` with any json serializable object. To restore the state again, call `getState()`

    // Within the webview
    const vscode = acquireVsCodeApi();

    // Get existing state
    const oldState = vscode.getState() || { value: 0 };

    // Update state
    setState({ value: oldState.value + 1 })

A `WebviewPanelSerializer` extends this persistence across restarts of VS Code. When the editor is shutdown, VS Code will save off the state from `setState` of all webviews that have a serializer. When the webview first becomes visible after the restart, this state is passed to `deserializeWebviewPanel`. The extension can then restore the old `WebviewPanel` from this state.

#### Methods

<span id="WebviewPanelSerializer.deserializeWebviewPanel"></span><span id="1914" class="ts" data-target="#details-1914" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">deserializeWebviewPanel</span>(<span class="ident">webviewPanel</span>: <a href="#WebviewPanel" class="type-ref">WebviewPanel</a>, <span class="ident">state</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

Restore a webview panel from its serialized `state`.

Called when a serialized webview first becomes visible.

The serializer should take ownership of this panel. The serializer must restore the webview's <code>.html</code> and hook up all webview events.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span id="state"></span><span id="1916" class="ts" data-target="#details-1916" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">state</span><span>: </span><span class="type-intrinsic">T</span></span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>Persisted state from the webview content.</p></div></td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>Returns</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr class="even"><td><span class="ts"><a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span></td><td><div class="comment"><p>Thenable indicating that the webview has been fully restored.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

### <span id="WebviewViewResolveContext"></span><span id="1928" class="code-item">WebviewViewResolveContext&lt;T&gt;</span>

Additional information the webview view being resolved.

#### Properties

<span id="WebviewViewResolveContext.state"></span><span id="1930" class="ts" data-target="#details-1930" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">state</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span> | <span class="type-intrinsic">undefined</span></span>

Persisted state from the webview content.

To save resources, VS Code normally deallocates webview documents (the iframe content) that are not visible. For example, when the user collapse a view or switches to another top level activity in the sidebar, the `WebviewView` itself is kept alive but the webview's underlying document is deallocated. It is recreated when the view becomes visible again.

You can prevent this behavior by setting `retainContextWhenHidden` in the `WebviewOptions`. However this increases resource usage and should be avoided wherever possible. Instead, you can use persisted state to save off a webview's state so that it can be quickly recreated as needed.

To save off a persisted state, inside the webview call `acquireVsCodeApi().setState()` with any json serializable object. To restore the state again, call `getState()`. For example:

    // Within the webview
    const vscode = acquireVsCodeApi();

    // Get existing state
    const oldState = vscode.getState() || { value: 0 };

    // Update state
    setState({ value: oldState.value + 1 })

VS Code ensures that the persisted state is saved correctly when a webview is hidden and across editor restarts.

### <span id="WindowState"></span><span id="2018" class="code-item">WindowState</span>

Represents the state of a window.

#### Properties

<span id="WindowState.focused"></span><span id="2019" class="ts" data-target="#details-2019" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">focused</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

### <span id="WorkspaceConfiguration"></span><span id="1330" class="code-item">WorkspaceConfiguration</span>

Represents the configuration. It is a merged view of

- _Default Settings_
- _Global (User) Settings_
- _Workspace settings_
- _Workspace Folder settings_ - From one of the [Workspace Folders](#workspace.workspaceFolders) under which requested resource belongs to.
- _Language settings_ - Settings defined under requested language.

The _effective_ value (returned by [`get`](#WorkspaceConfiguration.get)) is computed by overriding or merging the values in the following order.

    `defaultValue` (if defined in `package.json` otherwise derived from the value's type)
    `globalValue` (if defined)
    `workspaceValue` (if defined)
    `workspaceFolderValue` (if defined)
    `defaultLanguageValue` (if defined)
    `globalLanguageValue` (if defined)
    `workspaceLanguageValue` (if defined)
    `workspaceFolderLanguageValue` (if defined)

**Note:** Only `object` value types are merged and all other value types are overridden.

Example 1: Overriding

    defaultValue = 'on';
    globalValue = 'relative'
    workspaceFolderValue = 'off'
    value = 'off'

Example 2: Language Values

    defaultValue = 'on';
    globalValue = 'relative'
    workspaceFolderValue = 'off'
    globalLanguageValue = 'on'
    value = 'on'

Example 3: Object Values

    defaultValue = { "a": 1, "b": 2 };
    globalValue = { "b": 3, "c": 4 };
    value = { "a": 1, "b": 3, "c": 4 };

_Note:_ Workspace and Workspace Folder configurations contains `launch` and `tasks` settings. Their basename will be part of the section identifier. The following snippets shows how to retrieve all configurations from `launch.json`:

    // launch.json configuration
    const config = workspace.getConfiguration('launch', vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders[0].uri);

    // retrieve values
    const values = config.get('configurations');

Refer to [Settings](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/settings) for more information.

_Note:_ The configuration name must denote a leaf in the configuration tree (`editor.fontSize` vs `editor`) otherwise no result is returned.

<span id="WorkspaceConfiguration.update"></span><span id="1358" class="ts" data-target="#details-1358" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">update</span>(<span class="ident">section</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, <span class="ident">value</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">any</span>, <span class="ident">configurationTarget</span>?: <a href="#ConfigurationTarget" class="type-ref">ConfigurationTarget</a> | <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span>, <span class="ident">overrideInLanguage</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span>): <a href="#Thenable" class="type-ref">Thenable</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">void</span>&gt;</span>

Update a configuration value. The updated configuration values are persisted.

A value can be changed in

- [Global settings](#ConfigurationTarget.Global): Changes the value for all instances of the editor.
- [Workspace settings](#ConfigurationTarget.Workspace): Changes the value for current workspace, if available.
- [Workspace folder settings](#ConfigurationTarget.WorkspaceFolder): Changes the value for settings from one of the [Workspace Folders](#workspace.workspaceFolders) under which the requested resource belongs to.
- Language settings: Changes the value for the requested languageId.

_Note:_ To remove a configuration value use `undefined`, like so: `config.update(‘somekey’, undefined)`

- _throws_ - error while updating
  - configuration which is not registered.
  - window configuration to workspace folder
  - configuration to workspace or workspace folder when no workspace is opened.
  - configuration to workspace folder when there is no workspace folder settings.
  - configuration to workspace folder when [WorkspaceConfiguration](#WorkspaceConfiguration) is not scoped to a resource.

### <span id="WorkspaceEditEntryMetadata"></span><span id="832" class="code-item">WorkspaceEditEntryMetadata</span>

Additional data for entries of a workspace edit. Supports to label entries and marks entries as needing confirmation by the user. The editor groups edits with equal labels into tree nodes, for instance all edits labelled with “Changes in Strings” would be a tree node.

#### Properties

<span id="WorkspaceEditEntryMetadata.description"></span><span id="835" class="ts" data-target="#details-835" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">description</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A human-readable string which is rendered less prominent on the same line.

<span id="WorkspaceEditEntryMetadata.iconPath"></span><span id="836" class="ts" data-target="#details-836" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">iconPath</span>?: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a> | {dark: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>, light: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a>} | <a href="#ThemeIcon" class="type-ref">ThemeIcon</a></span>

The icon path or [ThemeIcon](#ThemeIcon) for the edit.

<span id="WorkspaceEditEntryMetadata.label"></span><span id="834" class="ts" data-target="#details-834" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">label</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

A human-readable string which is rendered prominent.

<span id="WorkspaceEditEntryMetadata.needsConfirmation"></span><span id="833" class="ts" data-target="#details-833" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">needsConfirmation</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

A flag which indicates that user confirmation is needed.

### <span id="WorkspaceFolder"></span><span id="2319" class="code-item">WorkspaceFolder</span>

A workspace folder is one of potentially many roots opened by the editor. All workspace folders are equal which means there is no notion of an active or primary workspace folder.

#### Properties

<span id="WorkspaceFolder.index"></span><span id="2322" class="ts" data-target="#details-2322" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">index</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">number</span></span>

The ordinal number of this workspace folder.

<span id="WorkspaceFolder.name"></span><span id="2321" class="ts" data-target="#details-2321" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">name</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

The name of this workspace folder. Defaults to the basename of its [uri-path](#Uri.path)

<span id="WorkspaceFolder.uri"></span><span id="2320" class="ts" data-target="#details-2320" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">uri</span>: <a href="#Uri" class="type-ref">Uri</a></span>

The associated uri for this workspace folder.

_Note:_ The [Uri](#Uri)-type was intentionally chosen such that future releases of the editor can support workspace folders that are not stored on the local disk, e.g. `ftp://server/workspaces/foo`.

### <span id="WorkspaceFolderPickOptions"></span><span id="512" class="code-item">WorkspaceFolderPickOptions</span>

Options to configure the behaviour of the [workspace folder](#WorkspaceFolder) pick UI.

#### Properties

<span id="WorkspaceFolderPickOptions.ignoreFocusOut"></span><span id="514" class="ts" data-target="#details-514" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">ignoreFocusOut</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">boolean</span></span>

<span id="WorkspaceFolderPickOptions.placeHolder"></span><span id="513" class="ts" data-target="#details-513" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">placeHolder</span>?: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span></span>

An optional string to show as placeholder in the input box to guide the user what to pick on.

### <span id="WorkspaceSymbolProvider"></span><span id="791" class="code-item">WorkspaceSymbolProvider&lt;T&gt;</span>

The workspace symbol provider interface defines the contract between extensions and the [symbol search](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/editingevolved#_open-symbol-by-name)-feature.

#### Methods

<span id="WorkspaceSymbolProvider.provideWorkspaceSymbols"></span><span id="794" class="ts" data-target="#details-794" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">provideWorkspaceSymbols</span>(<span class="ident">query</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">string</span>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>\[\]&gt;</span>

Project-wide search for a symbol matching the given query string.

The `query`-parameter should be interpreted in a _relaxed way_ as the editor will apply its own highlighting and scoring on the results. A good rule of thumb is to match case-insensitive and to simply check that the characters of _query_ appear in their order in a candidate symbol. Don't use prefix, substring, or similar strict matching.

To improve performance implementors can implement `resolveWorkspaceSymbol` and then provide symbols with partial [location](#SymbolInformation.location)-objects, without a `range` defined. The editor will then call `resolveWorkspaceSymbol` for selected symbols only, e.g. when opening a workspace symbol.

The lack of a result can be signaled by returning <code>undefined</code>, <code>null</code>, or an empty array.</p></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<span id="WorkspaceSymbolProvider.resolveWorkspaceSymbol"></span><span id="798" class="ts" data-target="#details-798" data-toggle="collapse"><span class="ident">resolveWorkspaceSymbol</span>(<span class="ident">symbol</span>: <span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>, <span class="ident">token</span>: <a href="#CancellationToken" class="type-ref">CancellationToken</a>): <a href="#ProviderResult" class="type-ref">ProviderResult</a>&lt;<span class="type-intrinsic">T</span>&gt;</span>

Given a symbol fill in its [location](#SymbolInformation.location). This method is called whenever a symbol is selected in the UI. Providers can implement this method and return incomplete symbols from [`provideWorkspaceSymbols`](#WorkspaceSymbolProvider.provideWorkspaceSymbols) which often helps to improve performance.

## API Patterns

These are some of the common patterns we use in the VS Code API.

### Promises

The VS Code API represents asynchronous operations with [promises](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise). From extensions, **any** type of promise can be returned, like ES6, WinJS, A+, etc.

Being independent of a specific promise library is expressed in the API by the `Thenable`-type. `Thenable` represents the common denominator which is the [then](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise/then) method.

In most cases the use of promises is optional and when VS Code calls into an extension, it can handle the _result type_ as well as a `Thenable` of the _result type_. When the use of a promise is optional, the API indicates this by returning `or`-types.

    provideNumber(): number | Thenable<number>

### Cancellation Tokens

Often operations are started on volatile state which changes before operations can finish. For instance, computing IntelliSense starts and the user continues to type making the result of that operation obsolete.

APIs that are exposed to such behavior will get passed a `CancellationToken` on which you can check for cancellation (`isCancellationRequested`) or get notified when cancellation occurs (`onCancellationRequested`). The cancellation token is usually the last parameter of a function call and optional.

### Disposables

The VS Code API uses the [dispose pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispose_pattern) for resources that are obtained from VS Code. This applies to event listening, commands, interacting with the UI, and various language contributions.

For instance, the `setStatusBarMessage(value: string)` function returns a `Disposable` which upon calling `dispose` removes the message again.

### Events

Events in the VS Code API are exposed as functions which you call with a listener-function to subscribe. Calls to subscribe return a `Disposable` which removes the event listener upon dispose.

    var listener = function(event) {
        console.log("It happened", event);
    };

    // start listening
    var subscription = fsWatcher.onDidDelete(listener);

    // do more stuff

    subscription.dispose(); // stop listening

Names of events follow the `on[Will|Did]VerbNoun?` pattern. The name signals if the event is going to happen _(onWill)_ or already happened _(onDid)_, what happened _(verb)_, and the context _(noun)_ unless obvious from the context.

An example from the VS Code API is `window.onDidChangeActiveTextEditor` which is an event fired when the active text editor _(noun)_ has been (_onDid_) changed (_verb_).

### Strict null

The VS Code API uses the `undefined` and `null` TypeScript types where appropriate to support [strict null checking](https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/7140).
